sample.title: How Barstool's Ex-CEO Built a Brand Amid Controversy | The Deal
sample.description:
In this episode of The Deal, Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly talk with Erika Ayers Badan, the former chief executive of Barstool Sports and current CEO of Food52, about what she’s learned from leading two “turnaround” companies. Badan tells the hosts how she led a company often laden with controversy, why she’s happy to grow talent that leaves and why she thinks it’s important to fail.

sample.title: Why younger Americans are saving money at such a high rate
sample.description:
As Americans live longer and worry about outlasting their money in retirement, a growing number are counting on one strategy for their future financial security: working longer.

Roughly 70% of U.S. workers who haven’t retired yet have considered pushing back their retirement date, according to a recent survey from F&G, an insurance company. Nearly half of the 2,000 adults surveyed said they’re afraid they won’t have enough money to retire.

sample.title: The $1 Trillion Tangled Web Of AI Deals Mapped Out
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence infrastructure deals lately has been staggering, with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, alone racking up around one trillion dollars worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments between companies like Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom, CoreWeave, Meta, Google, AMD, Microsoft and others have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes soaring. But some experts are worried that this tangled web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

Produced by: Magdalena Petrova
Animation: Christina Locopo
Additional Reporting: Kif Lewsing, Ashley Capoot, Mackenzie Sigalos
Edited by: Erin Black
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Why The AI Boom Might Be A Bubble?
sample.description:
Artificial intelligence is driving a wave of corporate investment unlike any in decades, with forecasts calling for $500 billion in global AI spending by 2026. Experts describe this as a "capex supercycle," but warn it may be propping up an otherwise fragile U.S. economy. If AI spending slows or fails to deliver on its promise, the consequences could ripple through markets, employment and economic growth.

0:00 Introduction
2:11 What happens if AI spending slows?
4:14 AI CapEx Supercycle
5:56 An uneven economic recovery

sample.title: What the U.S. can learn from Canada's banking system
sample.description:
FDIC data shows that the U.S. has nearly 4,500 banks. Canada has only 79 banks, according to the Canadian Bankers Association.

However, America’s banking industry is consolidating. FDIC-insured banks in the U.S. are down by nearly half since 2005.

sample.title: How Costco’s Clothing Business Became Bigger Than Abercrombie And Gap
sample.description:
Clothing may not be the first thing that comes to mind when shoppers think about Costco, but its apparel sales are more than some of the biggest brands like Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger and Old Navy. It has grown the category more than 40% over the past five years, which is significantly more than its competitors Sam’s Club and BJ’s. Costco has even now found itself facing a lawsuit by Lululemon for allegedly “duping” its products.  Watch the video to learn how Costco has become a major player in the fashion world.

Chapters:
0:00 Introduction
0:50 Chapter 1: Clothing boom
3:10 Chapter 2: Kirkland fandom
6:00 Chapter 3: Cheap prices, big profits

Produced by: Ryan Baker

sample.title: Sam Altman says OpenAI isn't 'moral police of the world' after erotica ChatGPT backlash
sample.description:
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said his company is “not the elected moral police of the world” after receiving backlash over his decision to allow content like erotica within ChatGPT.

Altman tried to clarify the move in a post on X on Wednesday, saying OpenAI cares “very much about the principle of treating adult users like adults,” but it will still not allow “things that cause harm to others.”

sample.title: Pope Leo slams 'ethical derailment' of continued world hunger
sample.description:
Pope Leo XIV made an urgent plea for global leaders to end world hunger, saying that allowing millions to go without food each day represented "an ethical derailment." In a visit to the Food and Agriculture Organization headquarters in Rome on its 80th anniversary, the Catholic pontiff also condemned the use of hunger as a weapon of war.
 
#pope #vatican #religion #catholic #hunger

sample.title: Thousands in UK sue Johnson & Johnson over talcum powder cancer risks | BBC News
sample.description:
A major legal claim has been filed in the UK against pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson, accusing the firm of knowingly selling baby powder contaminated with asbestos.
 
The claim involves 3,000 people and focuses on internal memos and scientific reports, which have been seen by the BBC.
 
The lawsuit - brought by KP Law - alleges that Johnson & Johnson (J&J) was aware as early as the 1960s that its mineral-based talcum powder contained fibrous forms of talc, as well as tremolite and actinolite. Both minerals are classified as asbestos and linked to potentially deadly cancers.
 
J&J denies the allegation as well as any claims it knowingly sold baby powder contaminated with asbestos.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#UK #Johnson&Johnson #BBCNews

sample.title: How does ROG Xbox Ally compare to other handhelds? #Gaming #BBCNews
Children caught up in Sudan’s deadly civil war | BBC News
sample.description:
Sudan is currently experiencing one of the world's worst humanitarian emergencies.
 
According to the UN, three million children under the age of five are acutely malnourished. The hospitals there are left overwhelmed.
 
Bashaer Hospital is one of the last functioning hospitals in Sudan's capital, Khartoum, devastated by the civil war which has been raging since April 2023. Many people travel hours to get to the hospital for specialist care.
 
Across the whole of Khartoum, children's lives have been rewritten by the civil war.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Sudan #Africa #BBCNews

sample.title: Police clash with anti-government protesters outside Peru's congress. #Peru #BBCNews
French PM Sébastien Lecornu survives no-confidence votes | BBC News
sample.description:
French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu has survived two no-confidence votes, after his pledge to suspend pension reform wins him the support of left-wing MPs.
 
He narrowly won the first motion by 18 votes and survived the second, brought by the far right, by a larger margin.
 
Marine Le Pen of the far-right National Rally previously said "this isn't a political crisis, it's a crisis of politicians”.
 
Lecornu only became PM in September.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#France #FrenchPolitics #BBCNews
